conclusion: Consider initial position and direction, power and speed, collision and deflection effects.
The car is positioned to the right of the blocks and appears to be moving towards the left.
Assume the car has a moderate initial speed that decreases upon collision.
Collision transfers kinetic energy causing movement; direction depends on angle of impact.
The car will first collide with the red block head-on.
Upon collision, the car will lose some speed and may deflect slightly; the red block will move forward.
After the first collision, the car will continue moving leftward with reduced speed and collide with the green block.
The second collision will further reduce the car's speed and cause the green block to move.
The car might collide with more blocks, but it's unlikely to gain enough momentum to collide with more than two blocks.
After the second collision, the car will likely come to a stop near the green block.
The exact stopping point will depend on the friction between the car and the surface.
The car will collide with the red block first, then the green block, and will eventually stop near the green block.
